Procedural_Stage: Opposition proceedings, Appeal to Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Hudson's Bay provided evidence of extensive use and advertising; BEYMEN lacks Canadian market presence
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed in part; BEYMEN's application restricted to certain wares and services
Burden_of_Proof: On opponent (Hudson's Bay) to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Strength of Hudson's Bay's evidence on use and recognition of BAY/BAIE marks
Legal_Rule: Confusion determined by distinctiveness, usage history, nature of goods/services, trade characteristics, and resemblance
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue type in appeal
Procedural_Issue: Introduction of new evidence on appeal
Grounds_for_Claim: Likelihood of confusion with existing registered trademarks
Review_Standard: Assessment based on statutory criteria under Trade-Marks Act
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Opportunity to present evidence and arguments at both stages
Key_Evidence_Considered: Usage and advertising history of BAY/BAIE marks; phonetic and visual similarity
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, opposition and appeal process
Defendant_Response: BEYMEN defended its right to register the mark
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of use, advertising, market presence
Remedy_Requested: Prevent registration of BEYMEN's mark due to confusion
Outcome: Partial restriction of BEYMEN's trademark rights
Remedy_Sought: Limitation of BEYMEN's trademark application scope
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative opposition followed by judicial appeal
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Confusing similarity to prior registered mark
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Registration of 'CLUB BEYMEN CLUB B' trademark
